The Happiest Man Alive | birth_date = {{birth date|1914|10|10}} | birth_place = [[Kirbyville, Texas]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1974|11|08|1914|10|10}} | death_place = [[Memphis, Tennessee]], United States | Origin = | Instrument = Piano | Voice_type = | Genre = [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[blues]], [[boogie-woogie]], [[country music|country]] | Occupation = [[Singer-songwriter]] | Years_active = 1933–1974 | Label = | Associated_acts = | URL = | Notable_instruments = }} '''Ivory Joe Hunter''' (October 10, 1914 – November 8, 1974){{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p378/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Ivory Joe Hunter|author=Bill Dahl |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=November 27, 2011}} was an American [[rhythm and blues]] [[singer]], [[songwriter]], and [[pianist]]. After a series of hits on the US [[R&B chart]] starting in the mid-1940s, he became more widely known for his hit recording, "[[Since I Met You Baby (song)|Since I Met You Baby]]" (1956). He was billed as '''The Baron of the Boogie''', and also known as '''The Happiest Man Alive'''. His musical output ranged from R&B to [[blues]], [[boogie-woogie]], and [[country music|country]], and Hunter made a name in all of those genres. Uniquely, he was honored at the [[Monterey Jazz Festival]] and the [[Grand Ole Opry]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 121 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} ==Early years== Hunter was born in [[Kirbyville, Texas]], [[United States]]. Ivory Joe Hunter was his birthname, not a nickname nor a stage name. As a youngster, Hunter developed an early interest in [[music]] from his father, Dave Hunter, who played [[guitar]], and his gospel-singing mother. He was a talented [[pianist]] by the age of 13, and as a teenager, Hunter made his first recording for [[Alan Lomax]] and the [[Library of Congress]] in 1933.{{cite book | first= Nigel | last= Williamson | year= 2007 | title= The Rough Guide to the Blues | edition= | publisher= Rough Guides Limited | location= London | page= 205 | isbn= 1-84353-519-X}} Hunter was also the uncle of [[Tower of Power]]'s original lead vocalist, Rick Stevens.{{cite web|url=http://www.rickstevensmusic.com/Rick-Stevens-Official-Biography.html |title=Rick Stevens Official Website Biography |publisher=Rickstevensmusic.com |date=2012-07-20 |accessdate=2013-03-22}} ==Radio and recordings== In the early 1940s, Hunter had his own [[radio show]] in [[Beaumont, Texas]], on [[KFDM]], where he eventually became program manager, and in 1942 he moved to [[Los Angeles]], joining [[Johnny Moore's Three Blazers]] in the mid-1940s. When he wrote and recorded his first song, "Blues At Sunrise", with the Three Blazers for his own label, Ivory Records, it became a nationwide hit on the R&B chart in 1945.[http://home.earthlink.net/~jaymar41/ivory1.html ''JammUpp'' 23: "Let Me Dream: Ivory Joe Hunter" by J.C. Marion] In the late 1940s, Hunter founded Pacific Records, and in 1947, he recorded for [[Four Star Records]] and [[King Records (USA)|King Records]]. Two years later, he recorded further [[R&B]] hits; on "I Quit My Pretty Mama" and "Guess Who" he was backed by members of [[Duke Ellington|Duke Ellington's]] band.{{cite web|url=http://www.tsimon.com/hunter.htm |title=Ivory Joe Hunter Page |publisher=Tsimon.com |date=2000-04-20 |accessdate=2013-03-22}} After signing with [[MGM Records]], he recorded "[[I Almost Lost My Mind]]", which topped the 1950 R&B charts and would later (in the wake of Hunter's success with "Since I Met You Baby") be [[Cover version|recorded]] by [[Pat Boone]] whose version became a number one pop hit. "[[I Need You So]]" was a number two R&B hit that same year. With his smooth delivery, Hunter became a hot R&B commodity, and he also began to be noticed in the [[country music]] community. In April 1951, he made his [[network TV]] debut on ''[[You Asked For It]]''. He toured widely with a backing band and became known for his large build (he was 6' 4" tall), his brightly colored stage suits, and his volatile temperament.{{cite book | first= Joe | last= Evans | year= 2008 | title= Follow Your Heart: moving with the giants of jazz, swing, and rhythm and blues | edition= | publisher= [[University of Illinois Press]] | location= | pages= 83–87 | isbn= 0-252-03303-5}} By 1954, he had recorded more than 100 songs and moved to [[Atlantic Records]]. His first song to cross over to the pop charts was "Since I Met You Baby" (1956). It was to be his only [[Top 40]] pop song, climbing to the number 12 position.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=ivory-joe-hunter-p378/charts-awards/billboard-singles|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Ivory Joe Hunter > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles )))}} While visiting [[Memphis, Tennessee]], in the spring of 1957, Hunter was invited by [[Elvis Presley]] to visit [[Graceland]]. The two spent the day together, singing "I Almost Lost My Mind" and other songs together. Hunter commented, "He is very spiritually minded... he showed me every courtesy, and I think he's one of the greatest."[http://books.google.com/books?id=TRnEdRBTih4C&pg=PA264&lpg=PA264&dq=%22showed+me+every+courtesy,+and+I+think+%22&source=bl&ots=UTHkWSixSh&sig=wCfVPy6_68ArjSENuS0evmfmUX0&hl=en&ei=PfEuTYbhOYPGlQfL19ikCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22showed%20me%20every%20courtesy%2C%20and%20I%20think%20%22&f=false Werner, Craig Hansen. ''A Change Is Gonna Come: Music, Race & the Soul of America'', University of Michigan Press, (2006)] Presley recorded several of his songs, including "I Need You So", "My Wish Came True" and "[[Ain't That Lovin' You, Baby]]". Hunter was a prolific songwriter, and some estimate he wrote more than 7,000 songs.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} ==Country comeback== Hunter's "Empty Arms" and "Yes I Want You" also made the pop charts, and he had a minor hit with "City Lights" in 1959, just before his popularity began to decline. Hunter came back as a country singer in the late 1960s, making regular [[Grand Ole Opry]] appearances and recording an album titled ''I've Always Been Country''.{{cite web|url=http://www.texasescapes.com/DEPARTMENTS/Guest_Columnists/East_Texas_all_things_historical/EastTexasCelebrities1BB1001.htm |title=East Texas Celebrities |publisher=Texasescapes.com |date=2007-06-23 |accessdate=2013-03-22}} [[File:Ivoryjoeh51.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Ivory Joe Hunter in his network television debut on ''[[You Asked for It]]'' (DuMont, April 1951)]] Country singer [[Sonny James]] issued a version of "Since I Met You Baby" and it topped the country charts in 1969, paving the way for Hunter's album ''The Return of Ivory Joe Hunter'' and his appearance at the [[Monterey Jazz Festival]]. ''The Return of Ivory Joe Hunter'' was recorded in Memphis with a band that included [[Isaac Hayes]], [[Gene "Bowlegs" Miller]] and [[Charles Chalmers]]. [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] covered "Since I Met You Baby" in 1969. ==Death== In 1974, [[lung cancer]] led to Hunter's death in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], at the age of 60.
